And wish when that time comes, you will love truly
(If you can ever doe so) you may finde
The worthy fruit of your affections,
True love againe, not my unhappy harvest,
Which like a foole I sow'd in such a heart
So drye and stonie, that a thousand showres
From these two eyes, continually rayning,
Could never ripen.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Y'ave conquer'd me:
I did not thinke to yield, but make me now,
Even what you will my Lelia, so I may
Be but so truly happy to enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: No, no, those fond imaginations,
Are dead and buried in me, let 'em rest.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I'le marry you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The Devill thou wilt Iulio
How that word waken'd me? come hither friend,
Thou art a foole, looke stedfastly upon her
Though she be all that I know excellent
As she appeares, though I could fight for her,
And run through fire; though I am starke mad too
Never to be recover'd, though I would
Give all I had l'th world to lye with her
Even to my naked soule, I am so far gone,
Yet me thinks still we should not doate away
That that is something more then ours, our honours
I would not have thee marry her by no meanes,
Yet I should do so; is she not a whore?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: She is; But such a one—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis true, she's excellent,
And when I well consider, Iulio
I see no reason we should be confin'd
In our affections; when all creatures else
Enjoy stil where they like.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And so will I then,

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: He's fast enough I hope now, if I hold him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You must not do so though, now I consider
Better what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Do not consider Angilo,
For I must do it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No I'le kill thee first.
I love thee so well that the wormes shall have thee
Before this woman, friend.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I was your counsell.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: As I was a knave,
Not as I lov'd thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: All this is lost upon me Angilo,
For I must have her: I will marry yee
When you please; pray looke better on me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay then no more friend; farewell Iulio,
I have so much discretion left me yet
To know, and tell thee thou art miserable.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Stay thou art more then she, and now I finde it.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Is he so?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Mistris.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: No, I'le see thee sterv'd first. Exit Lel.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Friend.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Fly her as I do, Iulio, she's a witch.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Beate me away then, I shall grow heere still else.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: That were the way to have me grow there with thee
Farewell for ever. Exit Ang.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Stay, I am uncharm'd,
Farewell thou cursed house, from this houre be
More hated of me then a Leprosie. Exit Iulio.

sp.speaker: Lelia.
sp.l: Both gon? a plague upon 'em both,
Am I deceiv'd againe? Oh I would raile
And follow 'em; but I feare the spight of people,
'Till I have emptied all my gall; the next
I seize upon, shall pay their follies
To the last penny; This will worke me worse
He that comes next, by heav'n shall feele their curse. Exit.

div.head: Scaena quinta.
div.stage: Enter Iacamo at one doore Fabritio at another.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O yee are a sweet youth, so uncivilly
To rayle and run away?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O are you there Sir?
I am glad I have found ye, you have not now your Ladies
To shew your wit before.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thou woult not, woult 'a?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What a sweet youth I am, as you have made me,
You shall know presently.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Put up your sword
I have seene it often, 'tis a Fox.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: It is so,
And you shall feele it too; will you dispatch Sir?
And leave your mirth out? or I shall take occasion
To beate ye, and disgrace you too.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Well since, there is no other way to deale with you
Let's see your sword, I am sure you scorne all odds,
I will fight with you—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How now? they measure, and Fab: get his Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Nay stand out,
Or by this light I'le make yee.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: This is scurvy
And out of feare done.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: No Sir out of judgement,
For he that deales with thee, thou'rt growne so boystrous
Must have more wits, or more lives then another,
Or alwayes be in Armor, or inchanted;
Or he is miserable.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your end of this Sir?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: My end is only mirth to laugh at thee,
Which now I'le do in safety; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Shart? then I am growne ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thou art,
And wilt be shortly sport for little children,
If thou continuest this rude stubbornenesse.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O God, for any thing that had an edge?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Fye, what a shame it is,
To have a lubber shew his teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Why dost thou laugh at me thou wretched fellow?
Speake with a pox; and looke ye render me
Iust such a reason—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I shall dye with laughing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: As no man can finde fault with: I shall have
Another Sword; I shall ye fleering puppy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Does not this testiness shew finely in thee?
Once more take heed of children, if they finde thee
They'le breake up schoole, to beare thee company,
Thou wilt be such a pastime, and whoo'te at thee:
And call thee bloody bones, and Spade, and Spitfire,
And Gaffer Madman; and go by Ieronimo,
And will with wispe and come aloft, and crack rope,
And old Saint Dennis with the dudgeon Codpeece:
And twenty such names.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No I thinke they will not.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Yes but they will: and Nurses still their children
Onely with thee, and here take him jacanto.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Gods pretious, That I were but over thee
One Steeple height: I would fall and breake thy neck.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: This is the reason I laugh at thee,
And while thou art thus, will do: tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I wonder how thou durst thus question me,
Pre'thee restore my Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Tell me but one thing,
And it may be I will: Nay Sir; keep out

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Well I will be your foole now, speake your minde Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Art thou not breeding Teeth?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: How? Teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Yes Teeth, thou would'st not be so froward else.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Teeth?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come, 'twill make thee
A little reumatique, but that's all one,
Weel'e have a Bib, for spoyling of thy doublet;
And a fring'd Muckender, hang at thy girdle,
I'le be thy Nurse, and get a Corall for thee:
And a fine Ring of Bells.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Faith this is somewhat
Too much Fabritio, to your friend that loves you;
Me thinkes your goodnesse, rather should invent,
A way to make my follies lesse, then breed 'em;
I should have been more moderate to you,
But I see ye despise me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Now I love yee,
There, take your Sword, continue so: I dare not
Stay now to try your patience, Soone I'le meet yee,
And as you love your honours, and your state,
Redeeme your selfe well to the Gentlewoman,
Farewell 'till soone. Exit Fab.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Well I shall thinke of this. Exit Jac.

div.head: Scaena Sexta
div.stage: Enter Host, Piso, and Boy with a glasse of wine.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Nothing 'ith world but a dri'd Tongue or two—

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Tast him and tell me.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Is a valiant wine,
This must be he mine Host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: This shall be Ipse,
Oh he 's a develish bitten wine, a Tyrant;
Where he layes hold Sir, This is he that scornes
Small Beere should quench him, or a foolish Caudell
Bring him to bed; no if he flinch I'le shame him,
And draw him out to mull amongst old Midwives.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: There is a Souldier, I would have thee better
Above the rest, because he thinkes there's no man
Can give him drinke enough.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What kinde of man?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: That thou mayst know him perfectly, hee's one
Of a left-handed making, a lanck thing,
As if his belly were tane up with straw,
To hunt a match.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Has he no beard to shew him?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Faith but a little; yet enough to note him,
Which growes in parcells here, and there a remnant:
And that thou maist not misse him, he is one
That weares his fore-head in a vellet scabberd.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That note's enough, he's mine, I'le fuddle him
Or lye 'ith sudds; you will be here too?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Yes, till soone, farewell and beare up.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: If I do not,
Say I am recreant; I'le get things ready.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: 'TIs strange thou should'st be thus, with thy discretion

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am sure I am so.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am well you see.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Keep your selfe warme then, & go home, & sleepe,
And pray to God thou maist continue so;
Would I had gon to'th Devill of an arrant,
When I was made a foole to see her: Leave me
I am not fit for conversation.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Why, thou art worse then I was.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Therefore leave me,
The nature of my sicknesse is not eas'd
By company, or councell, I am mad,
And if you follow me with questions
Shall shew my selfe so.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This is more then errour.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pray be content, that you have made me thus,
And do not wonder at me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Let me know, but what you meane to do and I am gon
I would be lo'ath to leave you thus else.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nothing
That needs your feare, that is sufficient;
Farewell, and pray for me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would not leave you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You must and shall.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will then: would yon woman
Had been ten fathom under ground, when first
I saw her eyes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yet she had been dangerous,
For to some wealthy Rocke of pretious stone,
Or mine of gold as tempting, her faire body
Might have been turn'd; which once found out by labour
And brought to use, having her spells within it,
Might have corrupted States, and ruin'd Kingdomes
Which had been fearefull (Friend) Go, when I see thee
Next, I will be as thou art, or no more.
Pray do not follow me, you'l make me angry.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Heav'n grant you may be right againe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Amen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Score a gallon of Sack, and a pinte of Olives to the Vnicorne.

sp.speaker: Above within.
sp.l: Why drawer?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A non, a non.

sp.speaker: Another boy.
sp.l: Looke into the Nags head there.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: Score a quart of Claret to the Bar,
And a pound of Sausages into the flower-pott.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: The Divell's in their throates, anon, anon.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Mull a pinte of Sack there for the women in the Flower-deluce, & put in ginger enough, they belch like potguns,
sp.l: And Robbin fetch Tobacco for the Peacock, they will not
Drunke till midnight else: how now how does my Master.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.l: Faith he lyes drawing on a pace.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: That's an ill signe.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: And fumbles with the pots too.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Then ther's no way but one with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: All the rest.
Except the Captaine are in Limbo patrum,
Where they lye sod in sack.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Does he beare up still.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: Afore the winde still, with his lightes up bravely
All he takes in I think he turnes to Iuleps,
Or has a world of Stoage in his belly,
The rest looke all like fire-drakes, and lye scatter'd
Like rushes round about the roome. My Master
Is now the louing'st man, I thinke above ground,

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Would he were always drunke then.
Within .Drawer.

sp.speaker: 2. B.
sp.l: Anon, anon Sir,

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: And swears I shall be free to morrow, and so weeps
And calls upon my Mistris.

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Then he's right.

sp.speaker: 1. B.
sp.l: And swears the Captain must lye this night with her
And bad me breake it to her with discretion,
That he may leave an issue after him:
Able to entertaine a dutch Ambassador,
And tells him feelingly how sweete she is,
And how he stoole her from her friendes i'th Countrey;
And brought her up disguiz'd with the Carriers,
And was nine nights bereaving her her maiden head,
And the tenth got a drawer, here they come.
Within cry drawer .Anon, anon, speake to the Tyger, Peter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Ther's my Bells boyes, my silver Bell.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Would he were hang'd
As high as I could ring him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Hoe Boy.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Robin, sufficient single Beere, as cold as christall,
Quench Robin, quench.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: I am gon Sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Shall we beare up still? Captaine how I love thee?
Sweete Captaine let me kisse thee, by this hand
I love thee next to Malmesey in a morning,
Of things transitory.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I love thee too, as far as I can love a fatt man.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Do'st thou Captaine?
Sweetly? and hartily?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: With all my heart Boy.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Then welcome death, come close mine eyes sweet Captaine
Thou shalt have all.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What shall your wife have then?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why she shall have besides my blessing, and a silver spoone
Enough to keepe her stirring in the world,
Three little Children, one of them was mine
Upon my conscience, th'other two are Pagans.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: 'Twere good she had a little foolish money,
To rub the time a way with.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not a rag,
Not a Deniere, no let her spin a Gods name:
And raise her house againe,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Thou shalt not dye though,
Boy see your Master safe delivered,
He's ready to lye in.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: God night.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: God morrow,
Drinke tell the Cow come home, 'tis all pay'd boyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A pox of Sack.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Marry God blesse my Buts, Sack is a jewell,
'Tis comfortable Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: More Beere boy.
Uery sufficient single Beere.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here Sir.
How is it Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: But ev'n so, so.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Go before finely Robin, and prepare
My wife, bid her be right and streight, I come boy
And Sirha, if they quarrell let 'em use,
Their owne discretions, by all meanes, and stir not,
And he that's kill'd shall be as sweetly buried;
Captaine, adieu, adieu sweet bully Captaine ne,
One kisse before I dye, one kisse.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Farewell Boy.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: All my sweet boyes farewell. Exit Host.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Go sleep, you are drunke.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, I'le see you at your Lodging,
You looke not lustily, a quart more.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No Boy.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Get us a Torch.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Tis day Sir.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Are not those the stars, thou scurvy Boy?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is not Charle-waine there, tell me that, there?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Yes;
I have paid 'em truely: do not vex him Sirha.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Confesse it Boy, or as I live I'le beate
Midnight into thy braines.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I do confesse it.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Then live, and draw more small Beere presently.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Come Boyes, let's hug together, and be loving,
And sing, and do brave things cheerely my hearts,
A pox a being sad; now, could I fly
And turne the world about upon my finger,
Come ye shall love me, I am an honest fellow:
Hang care and fortune, we are friendes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Do not you love me? I love you too dearely.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: No by no meanes; you are a fighting Captaine,
And kill up such poore people as we are, by'th dozens.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: As they kill flyes with Fox-tailes, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Me thinkes now as I stand, the Captaine shewes,
To be a very mercifull young man.
(And pre'thee Piso, let me have thy opinion)

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Then he shall have mercy, that mercifull is,
Or all the Painters are Apocrypha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I am glad you have your witts yet, will ye go?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: You had best say we are drunke.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Ye are.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yee lye.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Y'are Rascalls, drunken rascalls.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: 'Tis sufficient.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: And now I'le tell you why, before I beate yee,
You have been tampring any time these three dayes,
Thus to disgrace me.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: That's a lye too.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Well Sir,
Yet I thanke God I have turn'd your points on you,
For which I'le spare yee somewhat, halfe a beating.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: I'le make you fart fire Captaine, by this hand,
And ye provoke, do not provoke I'de wish you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: How do you like this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sure I am inchanted.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Stay till I draw.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Despatch then, I am angry.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: And thou shalt see how sodainly I'e kil thee.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Thou darst not draw, ye cold, tame, mangy Cowards
Ye drunken Rogues, can nothing make you valiant?
Not wine, nor beating?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If this way be sufferd
'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Go ther's your way, go and sleep:
I have pitty on you, you shall have the rest
To morrow when wee meete.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Come Lodowick,
Hee's monstrous drunke now, ther's no talking with him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I am so, when I am sober, I'le do more. Exit Lod. & Piso.
Boy wher's mine Host?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hee's on his bed a sleepe Sir. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Let him alone then: Now am I high proofe
For my action, now could I fight bravely,
And charge into a wilde fire; or I could love
Any man living now, or any woman,
Or indeed any creature that loves Sack
Extreamly, monstrously; I am so loving,
Iust at this instant, that I might be brought
I feele it, with a little labour, now to talke
With a justice of peace, that to my nature
I hate next an ill Sword: I will do
Some strange brave thing now, and I have it here:
Pray God the ayre keepe out; I feele it buzing. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Shee loves him too much, that's the plaine truth Fredrick
For which if I might be beleev'd, I thinke her
A strange forgetter of her selfe; ther's Iulio,
Or twenty more—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: In your eye I believe you,
But credit me the Captaine is a man:
Lay but his rough affections by, as worthy.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: So is a resty Iade, a horse of service,
If he would leave his nature, give me one
By your leave Sir to make a husband of
Not to be wean'd, when I should marry him;
Me thinkes a man is misery enough,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You are too bitter,
I would not have him worse.
Yet I shall see you hamper'd one day Lady,
I do not doubt it, for this heresie

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: I'le burne before; come pre'thee leave this sadnesse;
This walking by thy selfe to see the Divell,
This mumps, this Lachrimae, this love in sippets;
It fitts thee like a French-hood.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Does it so?
I am sure it fits thee to be ever talking,
And nothing to the purpose, take up quickly;
Thy witt will founder of all foure else wench,
I thou hold'st this pace; take up when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Before your Brother fly?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I can endure it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Heer's Raw-head come againe; Lord how he lookes?
Pray God we scape with broken pates.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Were I hee,
Thou should'st not want thy wish, he has been drinking
Has he not Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes but do not finde it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Peace and let's heare his wisedome.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You will mad him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I am somewhat bold, but that's all one.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: A short and pithy saying of a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: As I live
Thou art a strange mad wench.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: To make a parson.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ladyes I meane to kisse yee

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: How he wipes his mouth like a young Preacher;
We shall have it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: In order as you ly before me; first
I'le begin with you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: With me Sir?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Yes
If you will promise me to kisse in ease.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I care not if I venture.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I will kiss according to mine owne inventions
As I shall see cause; sweetly I would wish you,
I love ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes indeed do I,
Would I could tell you how.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I would you would Sir.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I would to God I could, but 'tis sufficient,
I love you with my heart.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Alas poore heart.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And I am sorry; but wee'l talk of that,
Hereafter if it please God.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ev'n when you will Sir.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Hee's dismall drunk, would he were musled.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You
I take it are the next.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Go to him foole.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Not I, 'a will bite me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: When witt? when?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Good Captaine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, and you play boa-peepe; I'le ha, no mercy
But catch as catch may.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Nay, I'le not defend ye.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Good Captaine do not hurt me, I am sorry
That ere I anger'd ye.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I'le tew you for't
By this hand witt, unlesse you kisse discreetly.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: No more Sir.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Yes a little more sweet witt,
One tast more o' your office: go thy wayes
With thy small kettle Drumes; upon my conscienc
Thou art the best, that e're man laid his leg o'er.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: He smells just like a Cellar,
Fye upon him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Sweete Lady now to you.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: For loves sake kisse him.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.l: I shall not keep my countenance.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Trye pre'thee.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Pray be not coy sweet woman, for I'le kisse ye,
I am blunt
But you must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: O God my sides.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Why ha, ha, ha? why laugh?
Why all this noyse sweet Ladyes?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Lusty Laurence,
See what a Gentlewoman you have saluted;
Pray God she prove not quick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Where were thine eyes
To take me for a woman, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Who art 'a, art 'a mortall?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am Fredrick

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Then Fredrick is an Asse,
A scurvy Fredrick to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sweet Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: A way woman;
Go stich and serve God, I despise thee woman,
And Fredrick shall be beaten; S'blood ye Rogue
Have you none else to make your puppies of, but me?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I pre'thee be more patient
Ther's no hurt done.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: S'blood but there shall be, Scab.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Help, help for loves sake.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Whos's within there?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: So now you have made a faire hand.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have kill'd me— Fal as kill'd.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Call in some Officers, and stay the Captaine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You shall not need.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: This is your drunkennesse.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O me unhappy Brother, Fredrick,
Looke but upon me, do not part so from me,
Set him a little higher he is dead.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: O villaine, villaine. Enter Fabritio.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O Sir my Brother! o my dearest Brother!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: This drunken trowgh has kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Kill'd him?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Yes.
For heaven God sake hang him quickly, he will do
Ev'ry day such a murder else. there is nothing
But a strong Gallowes that can make him quiet,
I finde it in his nature too late.

sp.speaker: Fabr.
sp.l: Pray be quiet,
Let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Some go for a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Oh what a wretched woman has he made me!
Let me alone good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: To what a fortune,
Hast thou reserv'd thy life.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Fabritio.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Never entreat me, for I will not know thee,
Nor utter one word for thee, unlesse it be
To have thee hang'd; for God sake bee more temperate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I have a sword still, and I am a villaine.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: &c. Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Away with him for heavens sake
He's too desperate for our enduring.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come, you shall sleepe, come strive not
Ile have it so, here take him to his lodging, and
See him laid before you part.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: We will Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ne're wonder, I am living yet, and well,
I thanke you sister for your griefe, pray keepe it
Till I am fitter for it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Do you live Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, but 'twas time to counterfeit, he was grown
To such a madnesse in his wine.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Twas well Sir,
You had that good respect unto his temper,
That no worse followd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If I had stood him, certaine one of us must have perish'd,
How now Franke?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart I tremble like an aspine.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let him come here no more for heavens sake
Unlesse he be in chaines.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I would faine see him
After he has slept, Fabritio, but to try
How he wil be; chide him, and bring him backe.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: You'l never leave till you be worried with him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come brother, wee'l walke in, and laugh a little.
To get this Fever off me.

sp.speaker: Clo
sp.l: Hang him squib,
Now could I grinde him into priming powder.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray will you leave your fooling?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Come, all friends. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Thou art enough to make an age of men so,
Thou art so crosse and peevish.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I will chide him,
And if he be not gracelesse, make him cry for't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I would goe a mile (to see him cry) in slippers
He would looke so like a whay cheese;

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would we might see him once more.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: If you dare
Venture a second tryall of his temper
I make no doubt to bring him.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: No good Franke
Let him alone, I see his vaine lyes only
For falling out at Wakes and Beare-baitings,
That may expresse him sturdy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Now indeed
You are too sharp sweet sister, for unlesse
It be this sin, which is enough to drown him,
I meane this sowrnesse, he's as brave a fellow,
As forward, and as understanding else
As any He that lives.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I doe beleeve you,
And good Sir when you see him, if we have
Distasted his opinion any way,
Make peace againe.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I will: I'le leave ye Ladies.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Take heed you had best, h'as sworn to pay you else.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I warrant you, I have been often threatned.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: When he comes next, I'le have the cough or tooth-ach,
Or something that shall make me keepe my chamber,
I love him so well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would you would keepe your tongue. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cannot keepe from this ungodly woman,
This Lelia, whom I know too, yet am caught,
Her looks are nothing like her; would her faults
Were all in Paris print upon her face,
Cum Privilegio, to use 'em still.
I would write an Epistle before it, on the inside of her masque
And dedicate it to the whore of Babilon, with a preface upon
Her nose to the gentle Reader; & they should be to be sold
At the signe of the Whores head i'th pottage pot, in what
Street you please: But all this helps not me;— I
Am made to be thus catch'd, past any redresse, with a thing
I contemn too.
I have read Epictetus twice over against the
Desire of these outward things, and still her face runs in
My mind, I went to say my prayers, and they were
So laid out o'th way, that if I could finde any prayers I
Had, I'me no Christian.
This is the doore, and the short
Is, I must see her againe.— He knockes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis I, I would speake with your Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Did she send for you?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No, what then? I would see her, prethee by thy leave.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Not by my leave; for she will not see you, but doth hate you, and
Your friend, and doth wish you both hang'd, w being so proper
Men, is great pitty, that you are not.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: For your sweet self in particular, who she resolvs perswaded your
Friend to neglect her, she deemeth whip-cord the most
Convenient unction for your backe and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Let me in, I'le satisfie her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And if it shal happen that you are in doubt of these my speeches,
Insomuch that you shal spend more time in arguing at the
Dore, I am fully perswaded that my Mistris in person from
Above, will utter her mind more at large by way of
Urine upon your head, that it may sink the more soundly
Into your understanding faculties.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: This is the strangest thing, good pretty soul, why dost thou use me so?
I pray thee let me in sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Indeed I cannot sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Thou art a handsome one, and this crosseness do's become thee.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Alas I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Especially to me; thou knowst when I was here, I said I lik'd thee of
All thy Mistriss servants.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: So did I you, though it be not my fortune to express
It at this present: for truly if you would cry, I cannot
Let you in.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pox on her, I must goe the down-right way: looke you
Here is ten pound for you, let me speak with her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I like your gold well, but it is a thing by heaven
I cannot doe, shee
Will not speake with you, especially at this time, she has affaires.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: This makes her leave her jesting yet, but take it
And let me see her, bring me to a place
Where undiscern'd of herselfe I may
Feede my desiring eyes but halfe an houre.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why faith I think I can, and I wil stretch my wits
And body too for gold: if you will sweare as you
Are gentle, not to stir, or speake, where you shall
See or hear, now, or hereafter: give me your gold, I'le plant you

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why, as I am a Gentleman, I will not.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Enough, quicke, follow me.
Why where's this maid, she ha's much care of her business. Nell?
I thinke she be sunke;— why Nell— whiew—

sp.speaker: Maid within.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I pray you heartily come away, oh, come, come, the Gentleman,
My Mistris invited, is comming down the street, and the banquet
Not yet brought out?— They bring in the Banquet

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: within .Nell, Sirha?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I come forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Now must I walk: when ther's any fleshly matters in hand, my
Mistris sends me of a four hours errand: but if I goe not
About mine own bodily businesse as well as shee, I am a Turke. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What, all wide open? 'Tis the way to sin
Doubtlesse; but I must on; the gates of hell
Are not more passable then these; how they
Will be to get out, God knows, I must try.
'Tis very strange, if there be any life
Within this house, would it would shew it selfe.
What's here? a Banquet? and no mouth to eate,
Or bid me do it? this is something like
The entertainment of adventurous Knights
Entring enchanted Castles: For the manner
Though there be nothing dismall to be seene
Amazes me a little; what is meant
By this strange invitation? I will sound
My Daughters meaning, e're I speake to her,
If it be possible, for by my voyce— Musique.
She will discover me! hark, whence is this.

lg.head: The SONG.
lg.l: COme hither you that love, and heare me sing
of joyes still growing
Green, fresh, and lusty, as the pride of Spring,
and ever blowing.
Come hither youths that blush, and dare not know
what is desire,
And olde men worse then you, that cannot blow
one sparke of fire.
And with the power of my enchanting Song,
Boyes shall be able men, and old men young.
Come hither you that hope, and you that cry,
leave off complaining,
Youth, strength, and beauty, that shall never dye,
are here remaining.
Come hither fooles, and blush, you stay so long
from being blest,
And mad men worse then you, that suffer wrong,
Yet seeke no rest.
And in an houre, with my enchanting Song,
You shall be ever pleas'd, and yovng maids long.

div.stage: Enter Lelia and her maid with a Night-gowne and Slippers.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Sir you are welcome hither, as this kisse
Given with a larger freedome then the use
Of strangers will admit, shall witnesse to you.
Put the gowne on him, in this chaire sit downe;
Give him his slippers: be not so amaz'd,
Here's to your health, and you shall feele this wine
Stir lively in me, in the dead of night.
Give him some wine; fall to your banquet Sir,
And let us grow in mirth; though I am set
Now thus far off you, yet four glasses hence
I will sit here,
And try, till both our bloods
Shoote up and downe to finde a passage out,
Then mouth, to mouth will we walke up to bed,
And undresse one another as we goe;
Where both my treasure, body, and my soule
Are your's to be dispos'd of.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Umh, umh.— Makes signes of his white head & heard.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You are old,
Is that your meaning? why, you are to me
The greater novelty, all our fresh youth
Are daily offer'd me, though you performe
As you thinke little, yet you satisfie
My appetite: from your experience
I may learn something in the way of lust
I may be better for. But I can teach
These young ones;
But this day I did refuse
A paire of 'em, Julio, and Angilo,
And told them they were as they were
Raw fooles and whelps. a a Ang. makes discontented signes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Pray God he speak not b b Maid lais her finger crosse her mouth to him.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Why speak you not sweet Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Umh.— Stops his ears, shews he is troubled with the Musick.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Peace there, that musique, now Sir speak
To me.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Umh.— Points at the Maid.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Why? would you have her gone? you need not keep
Your freedome in for her; she knows my life
That she might write it;
Thinke she is a stone?
Shee is a kinde of bawdy Confessor,
And will not utter secrets.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Umh.— Points at her againe.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Be gone then, since he needs will have it so,
Tis all one. Exit Maid.— Fath. locks the doore.
'Is all now as you would? come meet me then,
And bring a thousand kisses on thy lips,
And I will rob thee of 'em, and yet leave
Thy lips as wealthy as they were before.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes, all is as I would but thou.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: By heaven 'tis my Father.— Starts

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: And I do beseech thee
Leave these unheard of lusts which worse become thee,
Then mocking of thy Father; let thine eyes
Reflect upon thy soule, and there behold
How loathed blacke it is; and whereas now
Thy face is heavenly faire, but thy minde foule,
Goe but into thy Closet, and there cry
Till thou hast spoil'd that face, and thou shalt finde
How excellent a change, thou wilt have made
For inward beauty.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Though I know him now
To be my Father, never let me live
If my lust do abate.
I'le take upon me
To have known him all this while.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Looke, dost thou know me?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I knew yee Sir before.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: What didst thou do?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Knew you, and so unmov'dly have you borne
All the sad crosses that I laid upon you,
With such a noble temper, which indeed
I purposely cast on you, to discern
Your carriage in calamity, and you
Have undergone 'em with that brave contempt,
That I have turn'd the reverence of a childe
Into the hot affection of a Lover.
Nor can there on the earth be found but yours
A spirit fit to meete with mine.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: A woman? thou art not sure.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Looke and beleeve.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Thou art
Something created to succeed the Devill
When be growes weary of his envious course,
And compassing the world; but I beleeve thee
Thou didst but meane to try my patience,
And do'st so still; but better be advis'd:
And make thy tryall with some other things
That safelier will admit a dalliance:
And if it should be earnest, understand
How curst thou art, so far from heaven, that thou
Beleev'st it not enough to damn alone,
Or with a stranger, but wouldst heape all sins
Unnaturall upon this aged head
And draw thy Father to thy Bed, and hell.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd Sir, 'tis not against nature
For us to lye together; if you have
An arrow of the same tree with your bow,
Is't more unnaturall to shoot it there
Then in another? 'Tis our generall nature
To procreate, as fires is to consume,
And it will trouble you to finde a sticke
The fire will turne from: If't be natures will
We should not mixe, she will discover to us
Some most apparant crossenesse, as our organs
Will not be fit; which if we do perceive
Wee'l leave, and thinke it is her pleasure
That we should deale with others.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: The dores are fast; thou shalt not say a prayer,
'Tis not Gods will thou shouldst; when this is done
I'le kill my selfe, that never man may tell me
I got thee * * Fath. draws his sword. Angilo discovers himself..

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I pray you Sir, help ther, for Gods sake Sir.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hold reverend Sir, for honour of your age.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Whoe's that?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: For safety of your soule, and of the soule
Of that too wicked woman yet to dye.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What art thou? and how cam'st thou to that place?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am a man so strangely hither come,
That I have broke an oath in speaking this,
But I believe 'twas better broke then kept,
And I desire your patience; let me in,
And I protest I will not hinder you
In any act you wish, more then by word,
If so I can perswade you, that I will not
Use violence, I'le throw my sword down to you:
This house holds none but I, only a maid
Whom I will locke fast in as I come downe.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I do not know thee, but thy tongue doth seeeme
To be acquainted with the truth so well
That I will let thee in: throw down thy sword.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: There 'tis.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: How came he there? I am betraid to shame,
The feare of sodaine death strook me all over
So violently, that I scarce have breath He lets in Ang. and lockes the doore.
To speake yet: But I have it in my head,
And out it shall, that (Father) may perhaps
O're-reach you yet.

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.l: Come Sir, what is't you say?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: My Angilo, by all the joyes of love
Thou art as welcome as these plyant arms
Twin'd round, and fast about thee, can perswade thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I was in such a fright before thou cam'st,
You old mad fellow, (it will make thee laugh
Though it feared me) has talkt so wildly here—
Sirrha, he rusht in at my dores, and swore
He was my Father, and I thinke beleev'd it:
But that he had a sword, and threatned me—
I'faith he was good sport, good, thrust him out
That thou and I may kisse together; wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Are you her Champion? & with these fair words,
Got in to rescue her from me. Offer to run at him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hold sir,
I sweare I doe not harbour such a thought,
I speake it not, for that you have two swords,
But for tis truth.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Two swords my Angilo?
Thinke this, that thou hast two young brawny armes
And ne're a sword, and he has two good swords
And ne're an arme to use 'em; rush upon him,
I could have beaten him with this weake body,
If I had had the spirit of a man.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Stand from me, and leave talking, or by heaven
I'le trample thy last damning word out of thee.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Why do you hinder me then? stand away
And I will rid her quickly.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Would I were
Cleare of this businesse, yet I cannot pray.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh be advis'd, why you were better kill her
If she were good; Convey her from this place
Where none but you, and such as you appoint
May visite her; where let her heare of nought
But death and damning, which she hath deserv'd,
Till she be truly, justly sorrowful,
And then lay mercy to her, who does know
But she may mend?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But whither should I beare her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: To my house,
'Tis large, and private, I will lend it you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, and happily it fits
With some designe I have, but how shall we
Convey her?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Will they cary me away?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: For she wil scratch and kick, & scream so loud
That people will be drawn to rescue her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why? none can hear her here, but her own maid,
Who is as fast as she.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But in the streete?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why, we will take 'em both into the Kitchin,
There binde 'em, and then gag 'em, and then throw 'em
Into a Coach I'le bring to the backe-dore,
And hurry 'em away.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: It shall be so,
I owe you much for this; and I may pay you,
There is your sword, lay hold upon her quickly,
This way with me, thou disobedient childe.
Why do's thy stubborn heart beat at thy breast?
Let it be still, for I will have it search'd
Till I have found a well of living teares
Within it, that shall spring out of thine eyes,
And flow all o're thy body foul'd with sin,
Till it have wash'd it quite without a stain. They drag her.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Help! help! ah! ah!
Murther, I shall be murthered, I shall be murthered.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: This helps thee not.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Basely murdered, basely.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I warrant you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: THis roguy Captaine has made fine work with us.

sp.speaker: Piso
sp.l: I would the Devill in a storm would carry him
Home to his Garison againe; I ake all over,
That I am sure of; Certainly my body
Is of a wild-fire, for my head rings backward,
Or else I have a morise in my braines.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'le deale no more with souldiers: wel remembred,
Did not the Vision promise to appeare
About this time again?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Yes, here he comes:
He's just on's word.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: O, they be here together,
Shee's penitent, and by my troth I stagger
Whether (as now she is) either of these
Two fooles be worthy of her; yet because
Her youth is prone to fall againe, ungovern'd,
And marriage now may stay her, one of 'em:
And Piso, since I understand him abler,
Shall be the man; the other beare the charges,
And willingly, as I will handle it.
I have a Ring here, which he shall believe
Is sent him from a woman I have thought of:
But e're I leave it, I'le have one of his
In pawne worth two on't: for I will not loose
By such a messe of sugar-sops as this is:
I am too old.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It moves againe, let's meet it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Now if I be not out, we shall have fine sport,
I am glad I have met you Sir, so happily,
You do remember me, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I doe Sir.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: This is a short praeludium to a challenge.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I have a message Sir, that much concerns you,
And for your speciall good; Nay you may heare too.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: What should this fellow meane?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: There is a Lady,
(How the poore thing begins to warme already)
Come to this Towne, (as yet a stranger here Sir)
Faire, young, and rich, both in possessions,
And all the graces that make up a woman,
A widow, and a vertuous one: It workes,
He needs no broath upon't,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What of her Sir?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: No more but this; she loves you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Loves me?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes.
And with a strong affection, but a faire one,
If ye be wise and thankfull, you are made: ther's the whole matter.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am sure I heare this.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Here is a Ring Sir, of no little value:
Which after she had seen you at a window,
She bad me hast, and give it, when she blush'd
Like a blown rose.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But pray Sir by your leave—
Me thinks your yeares should promise no ill meaning.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I am no Bawd, nor cheater, nor a coarser
Of broken-winded women: if you feare me
I'le take my leave: and let my Lady use
A fellow of more forme; an honester
I am sure she cannot.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Stay, you have confirm'd me,
Yet let me feele, you are in health.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I hope so,
My water's well enough, and my pulse.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then
All may be excellent: pray pardon me;
For I am like a boy that had found money,
Afraid I dreame still.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Sir, what kind of woman?
Of what proportion is your Lady?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I'le tell you presently her very picture,
Do you know a woman in this towne they call,
Stay, yes, it is so, Lelia?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Not by sight.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Nor you Sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: These are precious Rogues
To raile upon a woman they never saw;
So they would use their Kindred.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: We have heard though
She is very faire and goodly.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Such another,
Just of the same complexion, making, speech,
But a thought sweeter is my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then
Shee must be excellent indeed.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Indeed she is,
And you will finde it so; you do beleeve me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes marry do I, and I am so alter'd—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Your happinesse will alter any man.
Do not delay the time Sir: at a house
Where Don Valasco lay, the Spanish Signior
(Which now is Signieur Angelos) she is.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But before you shew your selfe,
Let it be night by all meanes, willingly
By day she would not have such gallants seene
Repair unto her 'tis her modesty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'le goe and fit my selfe.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Doe, and be sure
You send provision in, in full abundance,
Fit for the marriage; for this night I know
Shee will be yours: Sir, have you never a token
Of worth to send her backe againe? you must,
Shee will expect it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes, pray give her this,
And with it all I have; I am made for ever. Exit Lod.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Well, thou hast fooles lucke; should I live as long
As an old oake, and say my prayers hourly
I should not be the better of a penny.
I think the Devill be my ghostly Father;
Upon my conscience I am full as handsome,
I am sure I have more wit, and more performance,
Which is a pretty matter.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Do you thinke sir,
That your friend Signeur Piso will be constant
Unto my Lady? you should know him well.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Who? Signieur Piso?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes, the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Why, you are wide Sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Is not his name Piso?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: No, mine is Piso.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed Sir,
And his is Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Then I am undone Sir,
For I was sent at first to Piso; what a rascall
Was I, so ignorantly to mistake you?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Peace.
There is no harme done yet.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Now 'tis too late,
I know my errour:
At turning of a Street,
For you were then upon the right hand of him,
You chang'd your places sudainly: where I
(Like a crosse Block-head) lost my memory:
What shall I do? my Lady utterly
Will put me from her favour.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Never feare it,
I'le be thy guard, I warrant thee, O, O,
Am I at length reputed? for the Ring,
I'le fetch it back with a light vengance from him:
Had better keep tame Devills, then that Ring;
Art thou not Steward?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Thou shalt be shortly

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Lord how he takes it?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: I'le go shift me streight;
Art sure it was to Piso?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: O too sure Sir.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: I'le mount thee if I live for't,
Give me patience heav'n to be are this blessing I beseech thee;
I am but man; I pre'thee breake my head
To make me understand, I am sensible.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Lend me your dagger, and I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: No
I believe now like a good Christian.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Good Sir make hast; I dare not go without ye
Since I have so mistaken.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: 'Tis no matter,
Meet me within this halfe houre at St. Margrets.
Well go thy wayes old leg, thou hast the trick on't. Exit. Piso.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How now? the newes?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Well, passing well, I have 'em,
Both in a leash and made right for my purpose.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am glad on't I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Whether man?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If all go right, I may be fast enough too.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cry you mercie Sir, I know your meaning,
Clora's the woman, she's Francks bedfellow,
Commend me to 'em, and go Julio
Bring 'm to supper all, to grace this matter;
They serve for witnesses.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.p: I will, Farewell. Exit Jul at one dore, & Ang, & Fa, at another.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Clora, Franck, and Fredrick, and Maid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sister, I brought you Jacamo to the doore,
He has forgot all that he said last night:
And shame of that makes him more loath to come,
I left Fabritio perswading him, but 'tis in vaine.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Alas my fortune Clora.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Now Franck, See what a kind of man you love,
That loves you when hee's drunk; If so
Faith I would marry him; My friends I hope
Would make him drink.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: 'Tis well consider'd Franck, he has such pretty humours then,
Besides being a Souldier, 'tis better he should love
You when hee's drunck, then when hee's sober, for then he
Will be sure to love you, the greatest part on's life.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And were not I a happy woman then?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: That ever was borne Franck. y'faith—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now? what sayes hee?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Faith you may as well tice a dog up with a whip, and bell
As him, by telling him of love and women, he sweares
They mock him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Looke how my Sister weepes.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Why who can helpe it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, you may safly sweare she loves him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Why so I did; and may do all the oathes,
Arithmatique can make, ere he believe me,
And since he was last drunk, he is more jealous
They would abuse him: If we could perswade him
She lov'd, he would embrace it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She her selfe
Shall bate so much of her owne modesty
To sweare it to him; with such teares as now
You see raine from her.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I believe 'twould worke,
But would you have her do't i'th open street?
Or if you would hee'le run away from her,
How shall we get him hither?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: By entreaty.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis most impossible, No, If we could
Anger him hither, as ther is no way
But that to bring him; and then hold him fast
Women, and men, whilst she delivers to him the truth
Seal'd with her teares, he would be plaine
As a pleas'd child; he walkes below for me
Under the window.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Wee'le anger him I warrant ye,
Let one of the maides take a good bowle of water,
Or say it be a piss-pott, and power't on's head.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Content hang me If I like not the cast of it rarely, for no question it,
Is an approv'd receipt to fetch such a fellow
Take all the women-kind in this house, betwixt the age of one,
And one hundred, & let them take unto them a pott or a
Bowle containing seven quarts or upwards, & let them
Never leave, till the above named,
Pott or Bowle become full, then let one of them stretch out
Her arme and power it on his head, add Probatum est, it
Will fetch him, for in his anger he will run up, & then let
Us alone.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Go you and do it. Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good Clora, no.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Away I say & do it; never feare, we have enough of that
Water ready distill'd.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why this will make him mad Fabritio,
Hee'le neither love me drunke, nor sober now.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I warrant you: what, is the wench come up?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Art thou there wench?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Looke out then if thou canst see him.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Yes I see him, & by my troth he stands so faire I could not
Hold were he my Father; his hat's of too, & he's scratching
His head.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O wash that hand I pre'thee. (I have throwne thee

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: God send thee good luck, this the second time,
Out to day, ha, ha, ha, just on's head.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: What does he now?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: He gathers stones, God's light, he breakes all the Street windows

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Whore's Bawdes, your windowes, your windowes.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Now he is breaking all the low windowes with his Sword,
Excellent sport, Now he's beating a fellow that laugh'd at him;
Truely the man takes it patiently; Now he goes downe the Street
Gravely, looking on each side, ther's not one more dare laugh.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Does he go on?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fabritio, you have undone a Maid Fran. kneeles.
By treachery; know you some other better,
You would prefer your friend to? If you do not
Bring him againe, I have no other hope,
But you that made me loose hope, If you faile me,
I ne're shall see him, but shall languish out
A discontented life, and dye contemn'd.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: This vexes me, I pray you be more patient lift her up
If I have any truth, let what will happen,
I'le bring him presently, Do you all stand
At the Street dore, the Maides, and all, to watth
When I come backe, and have some private place
To shuffle me into, for he shall follow
In fury, but I know I can out run him:
As he comes in, clap all fast hold on him,
And use your owne discretions.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Wee will do it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: But sudainly for I will bring him hither,
With that unstop'd speed that you shall run over
All that's in's way: and though my life be ventur'd
'Tis no great matter, will do't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thanke you,
Worthy Fabritio. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I ever knew no woman could abide me,
But am I growne so contemptible, by being once drunke
Amongst 'em, that they begin to throw pisse on my head?
For surely it was pisse huh, huh. seeme to smell.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Jacamo, how do'st thou?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Well, something troubled with watrish humours.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Foh, how thou stinck'st; pre'thee stand further of me
Me things these humours become thee better then thy dry
Chollerick humours, or thy wine-wet humours; ha?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You'r pleasant, but Fabrito know I am not in the wood of
Suffering jest.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: If you be not i'th mood I hope you will not be moody
But truely I cannot blame the Gentlewoman, you stood evesdropping,
Under their window, and would not come up.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Sir, I suspect now, by your idle talke
Your hand was in't, which if I once believe,
Be sure you shall account to me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: The Gentlewomen and the Maides have counted to you already
The next turne I see is mine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Let me dye but this is very strange; good Fabritio
Do not provoake me so.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Provoke you? you'r growne the strongest fellow; ther's no
Keeping company with you, phish; take you that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O all the Devills? stand Slave. Fab. give him a box o'th ear sodainly, & throws him from him, & goes his walls, whilst Iaca. drawes his Sword.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: follow me if thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Stay coward, stay.— Ja: runnes after Fabritio.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Fred. Fra. Clora. and Servant and Maid

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Be ready for I see Fabritio running,
And Jacamo behind him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Wher's the place.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That way Fabritio. Exit Fab.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Where art thou treacher? Fred. Clor, and Maid, lay hold on Jacamo.
What is the matter Sirs?
Why do you hold me? I am basely wrong'd,
Torture, and hell, be with you; let me go. they drag him to a chaire and hold him downe in't.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Good Iacamo be patient, and but heare
What I can say, you know I am your friend,
If you yet doubt it, by my soule I am.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: S'death stand away;
I would my breath were poyson.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: As I have life that which was throwne on you,
And this now done, were but to draw you hither
For causes weighty, that concerne your selfe
Uoid of all malice, which this Maid my Sister
Shall tell you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Puh, a pox upon you all; you will not hold me
For ever here, and till you let me go,
I'le talke no more.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.l: As you'r a Gentleman
Let not this boldnesse make me be beleev'd,
To be immodest; If there were a way
More silently to be acquainted with you
God knowes, that I would choose, But as it is
Take it in plainesse: I do love you more
Then you do your content, If you refuse
To pitty me, I'le never cease to weepe,
And when mine eyes be out I will be told
How fast the teares I shed for you do fall,
And if they do not flow abundantly,
I'le fetch a sigh shall make 'em start, and leap,
As if the fire weare under.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Fine mocking, fine mocking.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Mocking? looke how she weepes.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Do's she counterfeit crying too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Behold how the teares flow, or pitty her
Or never more be call'd a man.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: How's this? soft you, soft you my Masters: Is't possible thinke you,
She should be in earnest?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Earnest? I in earnest: she's a foole to breake so many sleepes,
That would have been sound ones, & venture such a face, &
So much life, for ere an humorous asse i'th world.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why Clora? I have knowne you cry as much?
For Julio, that has not halfe his worth,
All night you write and weepe too much I feare
I do but what I should.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: If I do write
I am answer'd Franck.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I would I might be so.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Good Fredrick let me go I would faine trye
If that thing do not counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Give me your Sword then.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, but take my word,
As I am man, I will not hurt a creature
Under this roofe, before I have deliver'd
My selfe, as I am now into your handes,
Or have your full consent.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is enough.

sp.speaker: Ja
sp.l: Gentlwoman, I pray you let me fele your face; I am an
Infidell, if she do not weepe: Stay, wher's my handkerchife?
I'le wipe the old wett off, the fresh teares come, pox on't
I am a handsome, gratious fellow amongst women, and
Knew't not Gentlewoman; how should I know these
For me? Is not your Mother dead?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: By heaven they are for you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Slight I'le have my head corld, and powderd to teares are morrow
By breake of day; If you love me, I pray you kisse me,
For If I love you, it shall be such love, as I will not be
A sham'd of, If this be a mock— kisses,
It is the hartiest, and the sweetest mock
That ere I tasted, mock me so againe — kisse againe

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fy Iacamo? why do you let her kneele
So long?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: It's true I had forgot it — lift her up,
And should have done this twelve-moneth; pray you rise
Fredrick, If I could all this while have been perswaded she could
Have lov'd me, dost thou thinke I had not rather kisse her
Then another should? and yet you may gull me for ought
I know, but if you do, hell take me If I do not cutt
All your throates sleeping.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Oh do not thinke of such a thing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Otherwise, If she be in earnest, the short is I am.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas, I am.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: And I did not think it possible any woman
Could have lik'd this face, it's good for nothing, is't?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Yes it's worth forty shillings to pawne, being lind almost quite
Through with velvet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis better then your Iulio's.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Thou thinkest so,
But otherwise, in faith it is not Franck — whilst Iacamo is kissing Franck.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Hist Iacamo; How do'st thou Boy? ha?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Why very well, I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Do'st thou perceive the reason of matters, and passages,
Yet Sirah, or no?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I have done simply for you, but now you are beatten to some
Understanding, I pray you dally not with the Gentlewoman
But dispatch your Matrimony, with all convenient speed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He gives good counsell.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And I will follow it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: And I you, prethee do not take it unkindly,
For trust me I boxt thee for thy advancement,
A foolish desire I had to joggle thee into preferment.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: I apprehend you Sir, & if I can study out a course
How a bastinadoing may any waies raise your fortunes
In the State, you shall be sure on't.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Oh Sir keepe your way, God send you much joy.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: And me my Iulio.
O God I heare his voyce, now he is true,
Have at a marriage Franck, as soone as you — Exeunt all but Fred.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Sir I would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What is your hasty busines friend?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The Duke commandes your present attendance at Court.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The cause?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: I know not in particular; but this
Many are sent for more, about affaires
Forraigne I take it Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will be there
Within this houre, returne my humble service.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: I will Sir. Exit Messenger.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Farewell friend, what new's with you?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Mistris would desire you Sir to follow
With all the hast you can, she is gon to Church,
To marry Captaine Iacamo, and Iulio,
To do as much for the young merry Gentlewoman,
Faire Mistris Clora.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Julio, marry Clora?
Thou art deceiv'd I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No sure Sir,
I saw their lips as close upon the bargaine
As Cockles.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Give 'em joy, I cannot now goe,
The Duke hath sent for me in hast.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: This note Sir: when you are free, will bring you where they are. Ex.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: reades .You shall finde us all at Signeur Angilo's,
Where Piso, and the worthy Lelia
Of famous memory are to be married,
And we not far behinde.
Would I had time
To wonder at this last couple in hell.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: You are staid for Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I come, pray God the businesse
Hold me not from this sport, I would not loose it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quinta.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: God give you joy, and make you live together
A happy paire.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: I do not doubt we shall.
There was never poore Gentleman had such a sodaine fortune,
I could thrust my head betwixt 2. pales, & strip me out of
My old skin like a Snake: will the guests come thou saidst
Thou sentest for to solemnize the Nuptials?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: They will, I looke for em ere this.

div.stage: Enter Julio, Jacamo, Fabritio, Franke, Clora.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: By your leave all.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: They'r here Sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Especially faire Lady
I aske your pardon, to whose marriage bed
I wish all good successe, I have here brought you
Such guests as can discerne your happinesse,
And best do know how to rejoyce at it;
For such a fortune they themselves have run,
The worthy Iacamo, and his faire Bride,
Noble Fabritio, whom this age of peace
Has not yet aught to love ought but the warrs,
And his true friends, this Lady who is but
A piece of me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Sir, you are welcome all,
Are they not Sir?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Bring in some wine, some of the wine Lodwick the foole. Exit Fath.
Sent hither: who ever thou bid'st welcome shall finde it

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: An unexpected honour you have done
To our too hasty wedding.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Faith Madam, our weddings were as hasty as yours
We'ar glad to run up & downe any whether, to see where
We can get meat to our wedding.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: That Lodwick hath provided too, good Asse.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I thought you Iulio, would not thus have stollen a marriage
Without acquainting your friends.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Why I did give thee incklings.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: If a marriage should be thus slubberd up in a play, er'e almost
Any body had taken notice you were in love, the Spectators
Would take it to be but ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This was the first, and I will never hide
An other secret from you.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Sir, yonder's your friend Lodwick, hide your selfe
And 'twill be the best sport—

sp.speaker: Piso
sp.l: Gentlemen, I pray you take no notice, I'm here.
The coxcomb Lodwick is coming in.

sp.speaker: Lodwick.
sp.l: Is that that Lady?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: That is my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: As I live she's a faire one; what make al these heere?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: O Lord Sir she is so pesterd—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Now will the sport be, it runnes right as Iulio told us

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Faire Lady health to you; some words I have, that
Require an utterance more private,
Then this place can afford.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I'le call my husband
All businesse I heare with his eares now.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good Madam no, bet I perceive your jest,
You have no husband, I am the very man
That walk'd the streetes so comely.

sp.speaker: Lel
sp.l: Are you so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes faith, when Cupid first did prick your heart
I am not cruell, but the love began
I'th Street I'le satisfie i'th chamber fully.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: To aske a Madman whether he be mad
Were but an idle question, if you be,
I do not speake to you, but if you be not
Walke in the Streetes againe and there perhaps
I may dote on you, here I not endure you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good Madam stay do not you know this Ring?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Yes it was mine, I sent it by my Man,
To change and so he did, it has a blemish,
And this he brought me for it; did you change it?
Are you a Goldsmith?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sure the world is mad,
Sirrah, did you not bring me this ring from your Lady?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes surely Sir, did I, but your worship must ev'n beare with me;
For there was a mistaking in it, and so: as I was
Saying to your worship, my Lady is now married.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Married? to whom?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: To your worships friend Piso.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: S'death to Piso?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: within. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes Sir I can assure you she's maried to him, I saw't
With these gray eyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why what a Rogue art thou then? thou hast made
Me send in provision too.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: O a Gentleman should not have such fowle wordes in's mouth
But your Worships provision could not have come in at a fitter time;
Will it please you to tast any of your owne wine?
It may be the Vintner has cozend you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pox I am mad.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You have alwayes plots Sir, & see how they fall out.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: You had a plott upon me, how do you like this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I do not speake to you.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Because you dare not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But I will have one of that old Rogues teeth sett in this Ring

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Do'st not thou know that I can beate thee?
Dost thou know it now? (discovers himselfe)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He beate me once indeed.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: And if you have forgot it, I can call a witnesse.
Come forth Piso— remember you it?

sp.speaker: Piso
sp.l: Faith I do call to minde such a matter.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: And if I cannot still do't, you are young
And will assist your Father in law.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: My Father in law?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Your Father in law, as sure as this is widow Lelia.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: How widow Lelia?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: I faith 'tis she, Sonne.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, let my provision go, I am glad I
Have mist the woman.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Have you put a whore upon me?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: By heaven you do me wrong, I have a heart
As pure as any womans, and I meane
To keep it so for ever.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: There is no starting now, Son, if you offer't
I can compell you, her estate is great,
But all made o're to me, before this match,
Yet if you use her kindly, as I sweare
I thinke she will deserve, you shall enjoy it
During your life, all save some slender piece
I will reserve for my own maintenance,
And if God blesse you with a childe by her,
It shall have all.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: So I may have the meanes
I doe not much care what the woman is:
Come my sweet heart, as long as I shall finde
Thy kisses sweet, and thy meanes plentifull,
Let people talke their tongues out.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: They may talke
Of what is past, but all that is to come
Shall be without occasions.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Shall we not make Piso, and Lodwick friends?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Hang'em they dare not be Enemies, or if they be,
The danger is not greate, welcome Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fredrick.
sp.l: First joy unto you all; and next I think
We shall haue warres.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Give me some wine, I'le drinke to that.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I'le pledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But I shall loose you then.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Not a whit wench; I'le teach thee presently to be a Souldier

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fabritios command, and yours are both restor'd

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Bring me foure glasses then.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You shall not drink 'em here, 'tis supper time,
And from my house no creature here shall stir,
These three dayes, mirth shall flow as well as wine.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Content, within I'le tell you more at large
How much I am bound to all, but most to you,
Whose undeserved liberality
Must not escape thus unrequited,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis happinsse to me, I did so well:
Of every noble action, the intent
Is to give worth reward, vice, punishment. Exeunt Om.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
The Prologue.
div.l: TO please you with this Play, we feare will be
(So does the Author too) a mystery
Somewhat above our Art; For all mens eyes,
Ears, faiths, and judgements, are not of one size.
For to say truth, and not to flatter ye,
This is nor Comody, nor Tragedy,
Nor History, nor any thing that may
(Yet in a weeke) be made a perfect Play:
Yet those that love to laugh, and those that thinke
Twelve-pence goes farther this way then in drinke,
Or Damsels, if they marke the matter through,
May stumble on a foolish toy, or two
Will make 'em shew their teeth: pray, for my sake
(That likely am your first man) doe not take
A distaste before you feele it: for ye may
When this is hist to ashes, have a Play.
And here, to out-hisse this; be patient then,
(My honour done) y'are welcome Gentlemen.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: IF you mislike; (as you shall ever be
Your owne free Judges) this Play utterly,
For your owne Noblenesse, yet do not hisse,
But as you goe by, say it was amisse;
And we will mend: Chide vs, but let it be
Never in cold blood: O' my honesty
(If I have any) this I'le say for all,
Our meaning was to please you still, and shall.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
